name.text: 37.1.1.5 General permutation take r at a time

questiontext.text:
In general the numbers of permutations of \(n\) objects taken \(r\) at a time is
\(\qquad n(n-1)(n-2)\dots (n-r+1)\qquad \) which is the same as \(\displaystyle{\quad\frac{n!}{(n-r)!}}\)
This is usually denoted by \(^nP_r\) so that   \[\displaystyle{\qquad ^nP_r=\frac{n!}{(n-r)!}}.\] If we allow repetitions the number of permutations becomes \(n^r\) (can you see why?).
